lines.text: [Coffin slaps the fancy cigarette lighter from Deke's hand as he tries to light a cigarette]
That's police brutality.
No, brother, that's cancer prevention.

One more word, soul brother. You had it made. Black folks would have followed you anywhere. You could've been another Marcus Garvey or even another Malcolm X. But instead you ain't nothin' but a pimp with a chicken-shit backbone.
Now what would a bail of cotton be doing in Harlem?
They say the badder the woman, the better the smell. Come sniff.
[Drunken man stumbles up during riot at police station]
Well, ain't this the "Goin' Back to Africa Rally"?
No, baby, it is the "Goin' Home Rally".
Was that black enough for you?
It ain't, but it's gonna be.
White guys?
White guys? They had on masks. How did you know they were white?

[crying]
Oh Lordy, help me!
I'm asking you. How do you know they was white?
They run white, dammit.
Any black man might rat on Whitey. I might myself.
Iris, cool it!
Don't tell me to cool it! You left me for the cops! Nigga, I oughta kill you!

[disguised as old woman to escape from jail]
Where's my pastor? Where's my pastor? What did you do with my pastor?
Wait a minute, hold it, just a minute, now! How the hell did you get in here?
She's with the delegation, don't you remember?
If ya'll don't give me back my pastor I'm gonna punch you in the stomach with this umbrella!
Now, watch it, lady.
O'Malley ain't here. He's been released.
Gimme back my pastor!
O'Malley ain't here, I tell you, and if you don't get the hell outta here with all that noise I'm gonna jail you.
[Iris leaves]
And stay out!
What's the matter with that old bag?
My people. My people.
What the hell do the attorney general, the state department, or even the President of the United States know about one god-damn thing that's going on up here in Harlem?
[Starts handling his revolver]
Say, do you have to play with that thing?
I'm insecure, Captain.
Is that the way to talk to anybody? Don't you know that black is beautiful?
Uncle Tom is what they are. My dance has got to say something about my people. Black people! We've got to set our peoples minds to thinking!
You took that ship, that big ol' lack ship, "Black Beauty," n' you smashed it down on that poor girl's head!
Another fine mess you got us into!
I got us into? Shut up and shoot!
Hey, Ed!
What is it?
Look at this. Cotton, from inside the meat truck.
One thing for sure, it ain't drugstore cotton.
What is it?
It's raw, unprocessed cotton. Like from a bale.
Ohhh, it's a long time since I've seen cotton like that.
Digger, you ain't never seen no raw cotton before. You were born and raised right here in New York, just like me.
[people outside police station demanding O'Malley return their money]
Digger and I will do our damnedest to get your money back. We promise.
Promises! Hell with promises!
Anybody out there ever hear of Coffin Ed or the Gravedigger make a promise we didn't keep?
[Crowd gets quiet]
Now, we may have broken some heads, but we never broke no promises.
You've got to understand Ed and Digger, sir.
I understand those two, all right. Too quick with their fists. Too flip with their talk. Too fast with their guns. And too damn black maniacs on a powder keg.
